title: Boy told he can’t go on trampoline because of prosthetic legs gets £2,500
text:
Zac Gordon was stopped from bouncing on a trampoline with his friends (Picture: PA)

A ten-year-old boy with prosthetic legs has received £2,500 after he was not allowed to use a trampoline.

Zack Gordon, from Co Down, was banned from using the equipment at We Are Vertigo trampoline park and offered other activities instead.

His parents said the move, which happened when he was seven years old, left him feeling ‘upset and sad.’

With the help of the Equality Commission, the family decided to sue for disability discrimination and have now settled out of court.

Zack’s father Patrick described his son’s prosthetic legs as being plastic and fibre glass with rubber feet.

Patrick Gordon and his son Zack at home in Killyleagh, Northern Ireland (Picture: PA)

Describing the incident in July 2017 in Belfast, Patrick said: ‘He went with the Killyleagh Summer programme to We Are Vertigo, where he watched the safety video and was given a wristband and socks for using the trampolines along with all the other kids.

‘Zack was then told he couldn’t use the trampolines. He was upset and sad and when he got home he stayed in his room.

‘His mother and I were angry and hurt.’

The Disability Discrimination Act includes a duty for service providers to think about what adjustments they should make to ensure people with disabilities can access them.

Director of legal services at the Equality Commission for Northern Ireland, Anne McKernan said: ‘Play is a vital part of growing up for all children and parents of disabled children will be keenly aware of the importance of focusing on what their children can do, rather than on what they cannot.

‘Service providers should anticipate that those with a disability, both adults and children, will want to access their services and they should give thought in advance to what reasonable adjustments will help to ensure that their services are available to all.’

We Are Vertigo trampoline park in Belfast settled the case with Zack and his family (Picture: PA)

In settling the case, We Are Vertigo agreed to liaise with the Equality Commission about improving access to its services for disabled customers.

In a statement, they said that the manufacturers of the trampoline equipment had issued guidance advising that patrons with prosthetic legs should not use the equipment.

They said: ‘This is a known issue with trampolines and other high adrenaline sports and adventure activities and not isolated to our facilities.’

They added that they had gone to ‘great lengths’ to provide access to people with disabilities and welcomed working with the Equality Commission ‘whilst ensuring that we adhere to important health and safety guidance.’
